heading: Earthquake
text: If a small earthquake hits somewhere in Missoula County, you will experience intensity 1 shaking. You probably won't feel a thing. If you do, it will be slight and won't cause any damage.

heading: Earthquake
text: If a small earthquake hits near here, you will experience intensity 2 shaking. A few people will notice slight shaking, typically those upstairs. Hanging lights might swing and trees wave.

heading: Earthquake
text: If a small earthquake hits near here, you will experience intensity 3 shaking. Most people indoors and on upper floors of buildings feel the shaking. It will cause parked cars rock slightly. It will feel similar to trucks passing by on a paved road.

heading: Earthquake
text: If a small earthquake hits near here, you will experience intensity 4 shaking. Many people will feel the shaking and some people sleeping will wake up. Windows, dishes, and doors will shift. It will feel similar to a truck hitting a building.

heading: Earthquake
text: If a magnitude 7 earthquake happens near here, you will experience intensity 3-5 shaking. The shaking will wake people up and cause dishes and windows to break. It will feel similar to a truck hitting a building.

heading: Earthquake
text: If a magnitude 7 earthquake happens near here, you will experience intensity 6 shaking. The shaking will be scary and cause heavy furniture to move and books to fall off shelves. It will be hard to walk around.

heading: Earthquake
text: If a magnitude 7 earthquake happens near here, you will experience intensity 7 shaking. It will be scary and hard to stand. Some people will run outside. Many buildings will be damaged and some chimneys will crack or fall.

heading: Earthquake
text: If a magnitude 7 earthquake happens near here, you will experience intensity 8. The major shaking will be scary and everyone will run outside. It will cause chimneys, walls, and factory stacks to crack and fall. Wood-frame houses will move if they're not bolted down.

heading: Flooding
text: In 1908, a massive flood swept away the Higgins Bridge in the City of Missoula and destroyed many homes. In 2011, homes on Tower Street and Kehrwald Drive flooded. Check out graphs of historic floods on the Clark Fork, Bitterroot, and Blackfoot Rivers.

heading: Landslide
text: Missoula County has seen landslides in the past, but they tend to be in forested regions after forest fires and thunderstorms come through. Rock falls and landslides have impacted" Highway 12 and Highway 200 before."

heading: Winter Weather
text: In February of 2014 several feet of snow fell in the Missoula Valley with high winds loading nearby peaks. A blizzard warning was issued and on March 2nd an avalanche charged down Mount Jumbo into the Rattlesnake Neighborhood in the City of Missoula. It caused damage to multiple homes, injuries, and one death.

heading: Summer Weather
text: In August 2015, a major windstorm hit the Missoula Valley with winds gusting up to 70-miles per hour. Dozens of trees were uprooted, power lines knocked down, and small fires started. 18,000 were without power at some time. It took days to remove debris from roads and restore power. Emergency crews were overwhelmed with phone calls of reported incidents.

heading: Earthquake
text: Earthquakes are unpredictable, but there are steps that you can take to prepare. Secure items that could fall, make a family communication plan and supply kit, practice "Drop, Cover, and Hold On," and know the location of utility shut offs. For more on preparing, check out Ready.gov.

heading: Earthquake
text: Scientists can't predict when earthquakes will happen, so prepare before one hits! For information during an event call the county information line at 406-258-INFO(4636) or watch local news. Interested in getting earthquake notifications? Sign up here.

subsection: A word from your emergency managers
heading: Earthquake
text: In the event of a large earthquake, the main priority for emergency officials will be to make sure all victims are accounted for and get them to safety. Then they will focus on restoring essential services and begin evaluating homes & buildings.

heading: Flooding
text: Make a flood plan and supply kit. Know where to go if waters rise and have your essential items ready. Prepare your home during a flood by bringing outdoor furniture inside, disconnecting electrical appliances, getting sand and bags, and evacuating if directed.

heading: Flooding
text: During floods, turn on your TV, radio, or weather app on your smart phone. You will receive the latest weather updates and emergency instructions from the local weather service. You can also check conditions on the NWS page.

subsection: A word from your emergency managers
heading: Flooding
text: If you live in a flood prone area YOU will be responsible for acquiring sand bags and filling them prior to a flood. It takes 30 DAYS for flood Insurance to kick in. If you think you are at risk sign up now! During a flood emergency managers' priorities are to keep people safe and restore essential services as quickly as possible.

heading: Wildfire
text: Experts recommend creating a defensible space of up to 200 feet from a structure. To find out how check out Firewise.org. If you are a private landowner looking to reduce forest fuels around your home, cost share programs can help. Talk to your local fire department for more information.

heading: Wildfire
text: For current updates check fire danger and air quality for your area. You should also sign up for emergency notifications at Smart911.com.

subsection: A word from your emergency managers
heading: Wildfire
text: If a wildfire threatens homes near you, follow emergency officials instructions and have essential items ready. Their top priorities are your safety and firefighter safety. Evacuating early is always better than too late! Know the three-stage evacuation plan "Ready, Set, Go".

heading: Landslide
text: Landslides are most common on barren, steep slopes where drainages come together especially, after rain events in areas that have recently been burned. If you live below an area like this be aware! Trees and vegetation help stabilize slopes.

heading: Landslide
text: Landslides typically cause road closures, but can impact neighborhoods too. The best thing you can do is to stay alert to local weather and hillslope conditions near your home. Check on road closures and conditions here.

subsection: A word from your emergency managers
heading: Landslide
text: It is unlikely that large-scale slides will occur in the county, but smaller ones could affect individual homes and roadways. Be aware of the risks around your home and if a roadway is blocked be patient as road crews work to re-open it.

heading: Winter Weather
text: Power will go out. Be smart, make a kit, and have essentials available when it does. Don't risk going out in the storm if you can avoid it. Find out more about how to prepare here.

heading: Winter Weather
text: Experts at the Weather Service Forecast Office near the Missoula Airport are on 24/7 with advisories, watches, and warnings to keep you safe if dangerous weather strikes the county! Check local news for weather forecasts and warnings or go to the NWS Page for more information.

subsection: A word from your emergency managers
heading: Winter Weather
text: If a massive snowstorm hits, the main priorities for emergency officials are to address public safety, power outages, and snow on major roadways. The best thing you can do to help is to stay inside, have a weeks' worth of supplies ready, and sign up for Smart911.

heading: Summer Weather
text: Power will go out. Be smart, make a kit, and have essentials available to you when it does. During a thunderstorm, stay inside and away from windows and doors. Find out more about how to fully prepare.

heading: Summer Weather
text: The Weather Service Forecast Office is in Missoula near the airport reporting 24/7 with advisories, watches, and warnings to keep you safe if dangerous weather strikes the county. Go to the NWS Page for more information. Storms can start fires too so check out local air quality here.

subsection: A word from your emergency managers
heading: Summer Weather
text: Trees will fall if winds are strong enough and power will go out. If trees fall on your property, you are responsible for calling a tree service company for removal. Emergency Official priorities are to make sure people are safe and then restore roadways and utilities. Be patient. Power will be back on as soon as possible.

heading: Earthquake
text: Large earthquakes cause gas lines to break, foundations to shift, bridges to collapse, and utilities to be disrupted. Evacuation routes could get compromised. Be aware that aftershocks, earthquakes that happen after the main one, are common and you will feel shaking in the days or weeks to come.

heading: Flooding
text: DO NOT try to walk or drive through floodwaters. It only takes 6 inches of moving water to knock you down and 2 feet to sweep a car away! Be alert for flash flooding. It is the #1 cause of weather related deaths in the US. If a warning is issued get to higher ground immediately.

heading: Wildfire
text: Wildfires are a typical part of Missoula County summers and will continue to be. With them comes SMOKE. Keep an eye on air quality ratings and stay inside if it gets bad. Steer clear of active fires and if you see one start call 9-1-1 to report it!

heading: Landslide
text: Landslides happen quickly and are hard to predict. They washout roads and destroy anything in their path. Embankments along roads are very susceptible. If you see sunken in pavement, mud on the road, and fallen rocks, there might be a landslide ahead. Don't drive near it!

heading: Winter Weather
text: Extreme winter weather can halt everything in and around town! It makes travel by foot or car extremely hazardous. Heavy snowfall and ice often knock out power, heat, and communication services. Pipes and water mains can freeze and break!

heading: Summer Weather
text: Flash flooding happens quickly and with little warning. If a flash flood warning is issued, take it seriously and get to higher ground immediately! Stay away from downed power lines and avoid touching metal in case lightning strikes.

heading: Landslide
text: The worst-case scenario is that mud, rocks, and debris flow into a neighborhood damaging homes, totaling cars, and injuring people. This is most likely if thunderstorms come through after wildfires have taken away the plants and trees that provided hillslope stability.

heading: Winter Weather
text: Across Missoula County winters come with below freezing temps, icy road conditions, and the potential for major storms. The valleys often get inversions causing poor air quality. Stock up on hot cocoa and get your winter supply kit ready.

heading: Winter Weather
text: There could be a blizzard in Missoula County. This means sustained winds or frequent gusts of 35 mph or more. Temperatures will be in the negatives and with wind chill even lower. Walking will be difficult and whole trees will sway. It will be hard to see due to falling or blowing snow.

heading: Summer Weather
text: Across Missoula County summers are hot! Along with people floating the rivers, taking hikes, and herding cattle you might also see thunderstorms, windstorms, and heat waves hit the county.

heading: Summer Weather
text: Severe thunderstorms can happen here. This means high winds, thunder, and lighting. They can lead to flash flooding (super fast floods) and include hail greater than an inch in diameter. You could see 60-80mph winds that cause trees to topple and damage to homes and power lines.
